name: Belize
description: Belize, officially the Belize District, is a small, easily traversable country located on the northeastern coast of Central America. Bordering Mexico to the north and Guatemala to the west, it boasts a remarkably diverse landscape, encompassing the world’s second-largest barrier reef, lush rainforests, and dramatic Mayan ruins. Belize is known for its rich cultural heritage, blending Mayan, Creole, Garifuna, Mestizo, and European influences, creating a vibrant and unique society.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: The administrative and political center of Belize.
quickFacts.detail: Established in 1981, Belmopan is a planned city designed to alleviate the pressure on the historic capital, Belize City.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: The total population of Belize as of 2023.
quickFacts.detail: The population is comprised of diverse ethnic groups, primarily Creole, Mestizo, Garifuna, and Maya.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.detail: This makes it one of the smallest countries in Central America.

quickFacts.label: Official Language
quickFacts.description: English is the official language of Belize.
quickFacts.detail: It was established as the official language during British rule.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.detail: The BZD is pegged to the US Dollar at a rate of 2:1.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.detail: Tourism and agriculture are the primary contributors to the economy.

climateData.title: Tropical Climate
climateData.description: Belize experiences a tropical climate with consistently warm temperatures and high humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is abundant, particularly during the rainy season.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Dry Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The dry season is characterized by sunny days, lower humidity, and less rainfall. It's the most popular time to visit for outdoor activities.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Wet Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The wet season brings heavy rainfall, cloudy skies, and higher humidity. Despite the rain, the landscape is incredibly lush and vibrant.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Hurricane Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Belize is susceptible to hurricanes during this period. Travelers should monitor weather forecasts and be prepared for potential disruptions.

naturalWonders.name: Great Blue Hole
naturalWonders.description: The Great Blue Hole is a massive marine sinkhole located off the coast of Belize. It’s a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a world-renowned diving destination.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: Formed during the last ice age, the Blue Hole plunges to a depth of 124 meters (407 feet). Its unique geological features and diverse marine life make it a truly spectacular sight.

naturalWonders.name: Cockscomb Basin Wildlife Sanctuary
naturalWonders.description: The Cockscomb Basin Wildlife Sanctuary is the world’s first jaguar preserve. It’s a haven for wildlife and a crucial area for jaguar conservation.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: Located in the Toledo District, the sanctuary encompasses a diverse range of habitats, including rainforest, swamp, and grassland. It’s home to a variety of species, including jaguars, tapirs, ocelots, and numerous bird species.

naturalWonders.name: Maya Mountains
naturalWonders.description: The Maya Mountains form the backbone of Belize, offering stunning scenery and a rich cultural heritage.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: These mountains are home to numerous Mayan ruins, including Xunantunich and Caracol. The area is also known for its waterfalls, caves, and diverse flora and fauna.

ecosystemData.title: Belize’s Diverse Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: Belize boasts an incredible array of ecosystems, from the vibrant coral reefs of the Barrier Reef to the dense rainforests of the Maya Mountains. These ecosystems are home to a remarkable diversity of plant and animal life.

biodiversityCategories.name: Marine
biodiversityCategories.description: Belize’s Barrier Reef is the second-largest barrier reef in the world, supporting a vast array of marine life.

statistics.details: A remarkable diversity of coral species thrives within the reef system.
The reef is home to over 600 species of fish, including sharks, rays, and colorful reef fish.

notableSpecies.name: Green Sea Turtle
notableSpecies.significance: A key indicator species for the health of the reef.

notableSpecies.name: Belizean Hogfish
notableSpecies.significance: A unique species found only in Belize.

biodiversityCategories.name: Forest
biodiversityCategories.description: Belize’s rainforests are incredibly biodiverse, supporting a wide range of plant and animal life.

statistics.details: A vast number of tree species contribute to the rainforest’s complex ecosystem.
Diverse mammal populations, including jaguars, tapirs, and howler monkeys.

notableSpecies.name: Jaguar
notableSpecies.significance: The apex predator of the rainforest.

activities.title: Adventure Activities in Belize
activities.description: Belize offers a wide range of activities for adventure seekers, from diving and snorkeling to hiking and exploring Mayan ruins.

activityCategories.name: Hiking
activityCategories.description: Explore Belize’s rainforests and mountains on foot.

activities.name: Cockscomb Basin Trail
activities.description: A popular trail leading to waterfalls and scenic viewpoints.

activities.name: Mountain Pine Ridge Trail
activities.description: A challenging hike through the Mountain Pine Ridge Forest Reserve.
activities.requirements: Sturdy hiking boots, plenty of water, rain gear

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
activityCategories.description: Experience the beauty of Belize’s waters through various water sports.

activities.name: Snorkeling & Diving
activities.description: Explore the vibrant coral reefs and marine life.

activities.name: River Tubing
activities.description: Relax and float down the rivers of Belize.
